com.itko.lisa.editor

Class ControllerBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisa.editor.ControllerBase
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Controller, com.itko.lisa.gui.ContextHelpSupport, com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, NamedObject, com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TestNodeInfo

    public abstract class ControllerBase
extends java.lang.Object
implements Controller, NamedObject
    Base class for all known Controller implementations

      • migrate

        public abstract void migrate(java.lang.Object testCaseObj)
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        If the test case object that you are going to maintain already existed in an existing test, then we need you to migrate the state of that exsiting element into your state here. Often, this is no more than just keeping a reference to the test case element object. At your discresion, you might do anything else you wish.
        Specified by:
        migrate in interface Controller
        Parameters:
        testCaseObj - the object to migrate (like the TestNode, FilterInterface, etc.)

      • generateName

        public java.lang.String generateName()
        Get an default name for the element. This is a default implementation and returns an empty string. Sub-classes like AssertControllerBase, DataSetController & TestNodeInfo MUST override it, since they are NamedObjects.
        Specified by:
        generateName in interface com.itko.lisa.test.NameGenerator
        Returns:
        String a default system generated name of the element

      • isGeneratedName

      • getNameType

        public NamedObject.NameType getNameType()
        Returns the type of Element Name. The name of an element (e.g. step) can be of one of the three types: defaultName generated by appending a numeric to element type (like Step1), user-defined that user would have typed in or saved into a test case, and calculated name that is system generated just like default name but more intelligently (WS-addUser for WS type step making addUser call)
        Specified by:
        getNameType in interface NamedObject
        Returns:
        NameType The valid values are DEFAULT_NAME, CALCULATED_NAME & USER_DEFINED_NAME

      • setNameType

        public void setNameType(NamedObject.NameType type)
        Sets the element name-type. The valid values are DEFAULT_NAME, CALCULATED_NAME & USER_DEFINED_NAME
        Specified by:
        setNameType in interface NamedObject
        Parameters:
        type -

      • makeEditor

        public abstract CustomEditor makeEditor()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        You are responsible for telling us what UI editor to use, so please give it here. You should probably just make one of these and cache it for all similar uses. The framework no longer calls this, just goes straight to showEditor, but you will likely still want one of these...
        Specified by:
        makeEditor in interface Controller
        Returns:
        the editor that will show and edit this controller's data

      • getEditor

        public final CustomEditor getEditor()

      • showEditor

        public final CustomEditor showEditor()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        When the framework needs to actually put the editor on screen, you'll get called here. This is called every time so you have the opportunity to sync the editor with the current version of your data.
        Specified by:
        showEditor in interface Controller
        Returns:
        the editor

      • refreshEditor

        public final void refreshEditor()
        This method allows the editor for this controller to be refreshed if the editor has been created.

      • clearEditor

        protected final void clearEditor()
        This method allows subclasses to clear out our cached editor instance, if there is one.

      • isEditorCompact

        public boolean isEditorCompact()
        The framework uses this method to determine whether the editor for this controller is designed to fit in the narrow inspector (true) or if it requires more real estate (false). At this level, we return false. If a subclass uses a small enough editor, they should override this and return true.
        Specified by:
        isEditorCompact in interface Controller
        Returns:
        true if the controller's editor will fit in the model editor object inspector or false if not.

      • isInInvalidState

        public boolean isInInvalidState()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        This is basically just a boolean version of isEditorValid
        Specified by:
        isInInvalidState in interface Controller
        Returns:
        true if the editor shown has problems

        Returns:

      • isEditorValid

        public java.lang.String isEditorValid()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        We expect you to inspect the editor and your internal data if appropriate, and return a human readable string of an error that should be addressed, or null if there is no problem.
        Specified by:
        isEditorValid in interface Controller
        Returns:
        string of the error to display or null if no problem

      • getLastErrorMessage

        public java.lang.String getLastErrorMessage()
        Description copied from interface: Controller
        Used by the GUI to display a better message. We want you to cache the last time your isEditorValid() message was an error. This is not required but will give the user the error when the framework is confirming that the test is in a valid state.
        Specified by:
        getLastErrorMessage in interface Controller

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        When we're shutting down the whole thing, we'll want to clean up model and viewer. If you override this, you must do a super.destroy() or you'll cause resource leakage. So behave!
        Specified by:
        destroy in interface Controller

      • destroy

        public static void destroy(java.util.List<? extends Controller> list)
        This is a helper method for destroying the controlers given in the specified list. Note that the list is also cleared.
        Parameters:
        list - the list of controllers to destroy.

      • gatherStepConnections

        public void gatherStepConnections(java.util.Collection<com.itko.lisa.test.StepConnection> stepConnections)
        This method is used for gathering information used in graphing and realizing who's talking to whom. Note: this data gets stale fast, so the framework calls this often if the user is graphing or changing step names.
        Specified by:
        gatherStepConnections in interface Controller
        Parameters:
        stepConnections - the collection to add all the step connections this editor knows about as StepConnection objects to.
        See Also:
        StepConnection
